reviewText: This is an interesting series with clever plots and personal relationships, including some special insights into the people of law enforcement.
Well written, acted, directed, edited.  It is a classical tv drama that shoe be watched by all who like classics

I love the humor between Sorensen and Sipowitz.  It gets better every episode.
I think it helps Andy to "father" Sorensen.  Also I loved the reference to his cousin Jekyll by Diane.  Not to mention all the potshots they take at psychiatric evaluations of the criminals.

It was another season the was really the official season of change. And I think it showed to be a good transition like in season 2 for what you would come to expect in season 3. Season 7 though to me in more ways gave the best interest as far as how every thing would be handled with everyone made for this first episode of the season to be of interest story line wise. Andy Sipowicz now being a widower now taking care of his son and what could possibly happen there. And seeing how Danny Sorenson would possibly play off to everyone that watches NYPD Blue. This first episode of season proved that all to be true and to me was the real start to be every ones interest in the change that turned out to be good.

One of the most down to earth police shows I've ever seen. I only found out about the program when I inadvertantly found it on Direct TV. They were showing one episode each night Monday through Friday. It's something that re-acquaints me with the language of New York that I miss now living in Georgia. The New York Language is totally different from the Georgia Language that sometimes is not understood. I would rate this show as five star as well as Blue Bloods and Chicago PD. All these shows delve into real police work and it's great.

i have loved that show since it was on and i am watching every single season...i have seen Bobby die probably ten times but the acting by Denis Franz is incredible. I probably won't watch the beginning as I could not stand whats his name...the one that left. I especially loved Jimmy Smits and the last person that played Sipowitz's partner, Mark Paul Glasier. It was a brilliant show and i hate that Denis Franz is not in anything anymore. He was a class act all the way. I love the NY scenes and I am hooked on seeing it all. After that i better get to Homeland and my other shows that i enjoy but this has been a real treat especially since i had a knee replacement recently and was watching more tv than usual...now i am back to the gym but i am still watching NYPD Blue every chance i get.

Nypd blue  being a former boss in Law Inforcemeat  I found this show one of the most realistic  made for TV. The other is on the top of the list  Bluebloods and law & order franchise. finally the movie  Business cought up to  The technical aspects as far as the proper Shields used for the different ranks in law-enforcement  when it comes the uniforms and  Shields in the past the police shows were good but not realistic as far as uniforms and equipment and vehicles if you do a police show drama it should be authentic exactly what you're trying to portray on the screen. Great job  finally  Real police offices can enjoy realistic stories about themselves. Thanks for a job well done.

Don't miss taking a look back.

I enjoy NYPD Blue with realistic story lines and without the graphic violence that so many of the current police series have now.  The violence doesn't contribute to the series but seems to be that the producers are trying to see how much they can get away with without having to issue a adult rating.  Having been in intelligence work I enjoy seeing realistic shows but there just isn't that much blood and guts in real life situations.  NYPD Blue is interesting without the gore and they were not counting on the "shock" affect back then to make the series popular.

Much of what I love about this series is of value to recovering alcoholics. It goes without saying that Andy's behavior reflects what is known as a dry drunk personality, someone who isn't drinking but continues to project their anger, fear and distrust on to everyone around him. He has a perfect excuse to play the role of a bad cop. It is not contributing to his well-being in the long run, but it is of great value to witness how difficult dry drunk behavior makes it on everyone in the "family". I have watched every season, some on TV years ago, but I will finish the rest of the seasons on Amazon. Thank you for continuing to offer this series.
Being a retired NYPD officer myself I will say this is the most authentic series I've seen in a long time.

Every season of this show, the finest police drama ever broadcast on network television (although, if it survives long enough, "Elementary" may give it a run for its money), gets five stars from me.

Some of my very favorite episodes of this whole series came in season 7.  They sprinkled a little more comic relief into the mix, and I always like that aspect of this show.  One episode in particular, entitled "Lucky Luciano," features the always amusing character actor Richard Libertini (Remember in the Steve Martin/Lily Tomlin treat "All of Me?"  He was the guy who said, "Back in bowl.") as the Italian immigrant Luciano, who Andy suspects killed his wife, or at least "egged on" his wife's cousin to do it.  Andy also suspects that he is not really Italian and tries to startle him as he "takes a crap" (his words), trying to get him to shout out some exclamation without the accent by suddenly banging violently on the stall door.  It doesn't work, but unbeknownst to any of us, Medavoy is trying to defecate in the next stall, and becomes rather disturbed at Andy's antics here.

Much of this season features Danny Sorensen screwing up his relationship with that nice Mary Franco despite her herculean efforts to keep him from doing it.  The travails of Jill Kirkendall with her slimeball husband also set the stage for the coming of the painfully delicious Connie McDowell (Charlotte Ross) to the squad, who Andy later marries.

I am really glad that Amazon Prime is carrying this entire series, the later seasons of which are not yet available on DVD.  The technical quality of their reproductions of the earlier seasons is noticeably higher than the one presented on the DVD sets.

Like most, I've waited awhile for the remaining seasons to release - well worth the wait. This was one of the few seasons I managed to watch when the show was on prime time - I had to catch the rest through syndication.

I'm still amazed at how this show kept up for so long at such a high level. I remember not liking Rick Shroder back in the day, big let down from Jimmy Smits and David Caruso. Giving a few years however, I have to say he was pretty darn good in his own way. It may be me but it seems like they ramped up the humor in the dialog between Sipowicz and Sorenson. Didn't see that with Simone or Kelly so much. Nice touch.

Great packaging. This is the way all DVD sets should be.

My only misgiving is with so many years passing since the show's been on the air it's not likely we'll see many special features. Too bad, I always enjoyed watching those.
Glad they're finally getting around to releasing the remaining seasons of this great series.  Looking forward to when they ultimately release Seasons 9 - 12.

I no longer watch TV--no cable or satellite or even rabbit ears--and I don't have much of an internet connection, none of the fancy streaming stuff for me, so I'm totally dependent on DVD to be able to enjoy good old television, not to mention the best damn drama ever produced for that medium.  I bought the first four seasons of NYPD Blue years ago and have begged and pleaded with everyone I could find to release the other eight seasons.  Finally SHOUT came along and I quickly snatched up 5 and 6...but then the same old foot-dragging crap started again.  There have been two 'delays' (so far) since I pre-ordered Season 7 and now it looks like I'm going to be starting on my 75th year before I get that package.  Is there any chance I'll actually get the entire show, all 12 years, before I die?  PLEASE!!!  PLEASE!!!  PLEASE!!!

...and I finally got it.  This season of NYPD Blue aired in 2000 which was right around the time my growing disaffection with television was getting a firm foothold, and I learned as I watched this long-awaited DVD that while some of the episodes seemed a little like 'old friends long out of touch' others were completely new to me.  All of them are great, of course, but I was especially happy to (a) see the gang do a totally comedic episode thanks to the guest appearance of the great Richard Libertini, (b) finally learn what actually happened, and how, to cause Andrea Thompson to leave the cast taking her Jill ("nobody counts except me and mine") role, which she admirably played to perfection, with her, and (c) catch a glimpse of Elizabeth Berkeley's (Showgirls) fine bare ass as she and Henry Simmons did a steamy bedroom scene....though of course that scene still doesn't hold a candle to the beautiful Sharon Lawrence's two nude scenes with star Dennis Franz--the shower scene and the even better "just don't do your Tarzan yell" bedroom scene.  I just can't get enough of this show and I hope Shout! delivers the rest of the seasons before my time on this planet expires.

I am revisiting all 12 seasons of NYPD Blue & enjoying each episode to the max. So interesting to watch for a second time and a decade or so later; to relive the drama, the in-depth stories; to remember the characters and relish in their development over the weeks. I think that's one important thing that goes toward making any film/TV/theater a draw--character development. Sucks me right in if it 's done so well as in NYPD Blue. I'm a NJ native--born & raised--finding myself living in Chicago after all these many years. I LOVE the intro to each episode--quick wonderful vignettes of life on the streets of beloved NYC. Nostalgia at its best. Watch a'ready!!

I never watched this show during the '90s when it first aired, but I find it very entertaining - mixing drama and subtle humor. Too late, Shout Factory--I bought Seasons 7-12 from the Brits (Amazon.co.uk) after Shout Factory gave me the runaround when I asked if there'd be any more beyond Season 6 (which is now in transit after being released today). The price is comparable so the only extra cost is an entry-level Sony player I tacked onto the order (that cost me the value of 1-1/2 of one of these sets). I can understand (sort of) their reluctance to jump in with both feet too hastily--manufacturing costs and all--but that doesn't allow for competitors getting the jump on you if you move too slowly. Funny how everybody in here is declaring Shout Factory to be God. A "god" that moves at glacial speed. Well they sold me one season with another due to show up here 3 days from now. But once Season 7 comes out in September--or so I've heard--I'll already have them all. But I wasn't about to wait 3 years (at best) for the rest of the series, no way.
there hasn't been a season of this series they had been bad so far looking forward to watching the rest of them

Thank you, Shout Factory, for really getting it in gear with the releases for this fine show.  3 releases inside of 1 year after we languished for 7 years between seasons 4 and 5 (your company's 1st release).  Glad you have the rights and are serious about getting the show in the fans hands.  Might we get a 4th season released this year in time for Christmas????  LOL.

I notice that, although there are only 5 seasons of "Blue" available with Season 6 scheduled for release about three weeks from now, all 12 seasons are available here on Instant Video. Which is obviously the source of all the more recent reviews here. Which wasn't the case until Shout Factory picked up the rights. So it's possible that Shout Factory provided Amazon with the downloads for it. I've been over to Shout Factory's site to ask them if there was some sort of timetable for release of the last 6 seasons in DVD, but they hedged on me and sent me a link to their "future releases" page. So they must be adopting a wait-and-see stance pending how their first two releases of Seasons 5 and 6 sell. Who knows how long that will take? Well, I've done my part--I just got the Shout Factory edition of Season 5 and their Season 6 is in my Shopping Cart waiting to be ordered when it comes out. As for this set and the last 5 seasons, I'm not waiting around any more. I went over to the UK site earlier this week and ordered Seasons 7-12 in Region 2 format. As for how to play them, it's a good thing an affordable player costs less than twice what each of these sets costs--over there as well as here. It may seem extravagant to buy a separate player for purposes of 3 dozen discs, but who knows? Maybe if I come across any more flicks in Region 2 format but aren't in our format, I won't have to pass on them. I'll have a player in that second format in my setup.

I can't say enough about how great this series is for the crime drama enthusiast.  NYPD Blue was the groundbreaker for this genre.  They were doing some unprecedented things with this series for its time.

Season seven has some of my favorite episodes: Lucky Luciano...the pain-in-the-a** neighbor who looks like a kid, and winds up clarifying the case for Andy...that Luciano poisoned his first wife, in Italy, and is taking his new girlfriend back to Italy, effectively self-extraditing himself to the jurisdiction of a previous murder...the moron. But it's going to cost Andy $500: the "kid" turns out to be an aggressive chocolate candy bar, and Mets memorabilia  salesman. Hahahaaa...

I thought I probably would not continue watching "NYPD Blue" after the death of Bobby Simone (played by Jimmy Smits) in season 6, since he was by far my favorite character. However, two new characters (Danny Sorenson played by Ricky Shroder and Baldwin Jones played by Henry Simmons) have captivated my interest. Perhaps most interesting of all is Andy Sipwicz, played by Dennis Franz, as an older detective who continues to grow and learn as he struggles with nearly overwhelming life challenges. The strengths of this series are great acting and fascinating development of individual characters and their relationships. The "police procedural" aspect of this show is nothing special. Otherwise, NYPD was a decade or two ahead of its time. I discovered it late and appreciate its obvious influence on shows in the new millennium .
Awesome, still holds up. As good as any police drama on TV today. Can't stop watching, hate the thought of getting to the end.

NYPD Blue was one of the most authentic television dramas ever produced. Unlike the shallow, crap today that seems to require super models as police officers and comedy every 6.3 minutes, NYPD was true to life. A show called "The Shield" managed to draw a large following with average looking actors as well. My only gripe with The Shield is the over-the-top criminal activity the team got away with day in and day out with no casualties until the last one or two seasons. NYPD Blue had casualties throughout the 12 or 13 seasons that it aired and the stars were not runway models. They looked like regular people doing a regular job. This is the same appeal that draws people to the Sci-Fi drama "The Walking Dead". They are everyday looking people who don't feel the need to crack jokes every 6.3 minutes.

Other than NYPD Blue which seems true-to-life and the Sci-Fi drama "The Walking dead" many other shows are saturated with over-the-top pretentious crap. I am turned off by shows involving serious, life-and-deatrh issues that feel the need for comedy relief every few minutes even while engaged with very serious issues. Most shows are like "Abbot and Costello Meet The Serial Killer". The slap-stick stupidity ruins the serious moments. Because I know comedy is going to occur throughout the program I do not allow myself to get to deeply engaged with the plot which makes me care even less about the outcome. This new generation of writers suck beyond belief. I assume they use focus groups to determine how many jokes should be cracked per a single crime show episode. The only thing missing are the old laugh-tracks from older comedy shows such as Three's Company or Gilligan's Island. NCIS should add the Three's Company laugh track to their stupid, corny, no-need-to-be there, comedy routines.

WHEN I WANT COMEDY TAKE A WILD GUESS AT THE TYPE OF SHOW I TUNE TO GET IT. HINT: IT ISN'T DRAMA...

Dennis Franz is the glue that holds this old, but not dated series together.  That is not to say the rest of the cast isn't good; they're great, but Franz's portrayal of a deeply flawed policeman, who despite his flaws, remains honest  and true to his profession and his fellow policemen is one of the greatest character portrayals on any TV series of any time.  Leading characters came and went, and they were good actors who gave outstanding performances and we missed them when they left, mourned them, but  Franz' portrayal of Sipowitz remains the best.  He's the character you love, even when his political incorrectness makes you wince.  He is the policeman you wanted on your side when you were seeking justice and he is the policeman you'd least want to meet if you were the perp.  NYPD Blue is an ensemble show, and as previously stated, all are great, but Sipowitz, with all his flaws, and all his humanity, remains the reason  this is one of the greatest TV shows ever.

I love NYPD Blue because it's so well written, has such great talent, and it is not overwhelmed with sex scenes.  Yes it contains some, but it's not all the time.  The stories are about people on the street and the everyday happenings of a cop shop.  Simply one of the best shows of its kind out there.

The previous season to this one was rough for fans of NYPD Blue.  Everyone knew Bobby Simone would be written out early in the season, as Jimy Smits had decided to move on.  This knowledge in no way made the slow, sad death of Bobby any easier to bear.  Then, shockingly, Andy's wife of several seasons, Sylvia, is gunned down before the season finale, adding to the list of tragedies heaped on his shoulders.  Maybe because of the heaviness of these episodes, Season 7 has an overall lighter tone, while keeping the gritty nature the show was always known for.  James Martinez exits the show after getting promoted to sergeant.  To fill his spot, the character of Baldwin Jones, who would remain until the series' end, is introduced.  Danny Sorenson has a relationship with fellow cop Mary Franco, but gradually gets closer to Diane.  Danny's self-destructive tendencies become more evident, foreshadowing his downfall by the end of Season 8.  Season 7 has some excellent episodes, and just like the rest of the seasons, benefits from incredibly high quality writing and acting.  This was a fantastic season of one of TV's truly great dramas.
Characters continue to evolve or become replaced with others; Andy Sipowicz still stars as the most evolving and the most colorful one.
Well scripted and acted.  Never a dull moment.  One of the best series ever on television...but only if you like police and action themes.

I choose a four star due to the fact that there were multiple times the streaming signal shorted out and a moment of static was heard at the same time. This series is very entertaining and would recommend it to anyone enjoying drama and good acting. Most episodes have been excellent, especially when CC was available.

When NYPD Blue first arrived on network television in the early 1990s I was one of those people who gave it a pass, mainly because I wasn't interested in the "adult content." I had enough problems of my own to deal with without watching lots of slop on TV as well. Some friends watched it and told me that I would probably enjoy it because the stories were so good even though they were fairly harsh at times. Still, I didn't watch it for a couple years.

When I did I was sorry I'd waited. Not because of the sexual and violent content, but because it was so well written. The characters were so well fleshed out that they became very real to me. And I knew a few cops in my hometown and they were the same way! They seemed to have the same flaws even though they were committed to keeping our streets safe.

By season 7 these guys were like old friends. Sipowicz has gone through two partners by now and the entire squad looks pretty different from the earliest days of the show. The production moved into a groove that remained until the end of the series- even after David Milch left. The stories, cocredited to Bill Clark, had a cohesion that kicked the whole series up a notch or two.

If I remember right this was Milch's last season but he wasn't coasting through it. There are some great stories and some character developments that network TV wouldn't have been able to do prior to NYPD Blue. The care given to each storyline is amazing even though I'm sure many details were dropped because the writers couldn't jam every bit of detail into the scripts. Still, the series is like a novel for television that lasted 12 years and around 300 episodes. This season hits some plot points that play out over a long time.

I'm more and more convinced that NYPD Blue was the best show on television and still holds up better than anything else produced in the 1990s.
Re-watching all the great NYPD Blue series.  Good drama and character development with each new season.  Looking forward to watching even more.

I think this is the first cop show that attempts to show the personal hardships and stresses that plague the men and women in blue.  The good people who put their lives on the line for us every day are dealing with so much in their personal lives that it is amazing, that they can even do their jobs half as well as they do.  I appreciate the writers in this series letting us look behind the badge, the uniform and the bureaucracy to see the obstacles and the personal sacrifices of our protectors.  the characters are real people that we know and see everyday in our own lives.
